channel.title: NYT > U.S. News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2020 The New York Times Company

item.title: Coronavirus Live Updates: Pandemic Enters New Phase as Hot Spots Shift
item.description: Some Americans face economic ruin with government aid set to end. Masks become a flash point for businesses, and the C.D.C. proposes changes that would remake the workplace.
item.media:credit: Philip Cheung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Downtown Los Angeles earlier this month.

item.title: Indian Casinos in California Reopen, Defying the Governor
item.description: Some casinos swung open their doors last week despite health concerns. “This virus does not recognize jurisdictional boundaries,” Gov. Gavin Newsom wrote to tribal leaders.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Fuller
item.media:description: People waited outside of the Viejas Casino and Resort in Alpine, Calif., last week.

item.title: George Floyd Protests in Minneapolis: Live Updates
item.description: A building was set on fire and protesters clashed with police officers as demonstrations escalated for a third night after Mr. Floyd’s death. Rallies were also held in New York and Denver.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters lit fires and burned buildings in Minneapolis overnight Wednesday.

item.title: An ‘Avalanche of Evictions’ Could Be Bearing Down on America’s Renters
item.description: The economic downturn is shaping up to be particularly devastating for renters, who are more likely to be lower-income and work hourly jobs cut during the pandemic.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Mervosh
item.media:credit: Maddie McGarvey for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sandy Naffah in her apartment in Euclid, Ohio, with her dog, Shadow. Ms. Naffah is worried about eviction after losing two part-time jobs during the coronavirus pandemic.

item.title: Pompeo Releases Letter Clearing Him of Violating Law With Kansas Trips
item.description: Secretary of State Mike Pompeo also criticized Senator Robert Menendez, Democrat of New Jersey, who has opened an investigation into the firing of the State Department inspector general.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger and Edward Wong
item.media:description: Secretary of State Mike Pompeo did not mention the letter, dated Jan. 21, when he dismissed charges related to investigations by the department’s inspector general.

item.title: National Guard Called as Minneapolis Erupts in Solidarity for George Floyd
item.description: Violence in the streets prompts officials to call in troops and vow a swift federal review of troubling videotaped arrest.
item.dc:creator: Matt Furber, John Eligon and Audra D. S. Burch
item.media:credit: Tim Gruber for The New York Times
item.media:description: Outrage over the death of George Floyd sent hundreds of residents spilling onto the streets of Minneapolis over the past couple of nights.

item.title: Explaining President Trump's Executive Order Targeting Social Media
item.description: The president wants to narrow legal protections for companies like Twitter after it began appending fact-check labels to his postings.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage
item.media:description: A 1996 law protects internet content providers like Twitter from being sued.

item.title: American Priest Moves a Step Closer to Sainthood
item.description: Pope Francis has credited a miracle to the Rev. Michael J. McGivney, a Connecticut priest who died in the flu pandemic of 1889-90 at 38.
item.dc:creator: Sandra E. Garcia
item.media:credit: Thomas McDonald for The New York Times
item.media:description: A statue of Rev. Michael J. McGivney in the basement of St. Mary’s Church in New Haven, Conn.

item.title: Trump Officials Consider Defying Congress to Sell More Weapons to Saudi Arabia
item.description: The administration has informed lawmakers that it intends to allow the sale of munitions worth $478 million to the kingdom, setting up a potential clash with Congress.
item.dc:creator: Catie Edmondson
item.media:description: President Trump with Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman of Saudi Arabia at the Group of 20 summit in Osaka, Japan, last year.

item.title: Coronavirus Aid: Millions Can See Its End, and They’re Scared
item.description: Emergency programs have cushioned the shutdown’s impact on workers and businesses and lifted the economy, but may not outlast the coronavirus crisis.
item.dc:creator: Ben Casselman
item.category: Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)
item.media:credit: Mason Trinca for The New York Times
item.media:description: After Julie Glasser was laid off in March, benefits from the CARES Act provided “a huge relief,” she said, but “then it’s also this thought bubble up above my head of, ‘How long is this going to last?’”

item.title: Does a Crisis Spur Political Unity? Not This Pandemic
item.description: Insults, accusations and shaming characterize the current political environment even as leaders must come together at some point.
item.dc:creator: Carl Hulse
item.category: Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)
item.media:description: Republican lawmakers practicing social distancing during a news conference this week.

item.title: U.S. Accuses Russian Military Hackers of Attack on Email Servers
item.description: The unusually public complaint showed that American spy agencies are becoming more aggressive in calling out Moscow’s interference as the presidential election approaches.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes and David E. Sanger
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates
item.media:description: Hackers from the G.R.U., Russia’s military intelligence unit, were behind both the theft of documents on the Democratic National Committee’s servers and the hack of the Clinton campaign in 2016.

item.title: Albert Krieger, a Bulldog of the Criminal Defense Bar, Dies at 96
item.description: His clients included John Gotti, Joseph Bonanno, Miami’s “cocaine cowboys” and the defendants in the Wounded Knee siege.
item.dc:creator: Sam Roberts
item.category: National Assn of Criminal Defense Lawyers
item.media:description: Albert Krieger, left, with John D’Amato of the Gambino crime family during the trial of John Gotti, whom Mr. Krieger represented, in 1992. “It is the defense lawyer who says to the all-powerful government that it must prove that the charge was properly brought,” Mr. Krieger once said.

item.title: California Regulators Back PG&E Bankruptcy Plan
item.description: The vote increases the likelihood that the utility will resolve its case by a June 30 deadline and get future liability protection from the state.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Penn
item.media:description: Pacific Gas & Electric, California’s biggest utility, sought bankruptcy protection after amassing $30 billion in liabilities related to wildfires caused by its equipment.

item.title: Trump Signs Executive Order on Social Media, Claiming to Protect ‘Free Speech’
item.description: The president and his allies have often accused Twitter and Facebook of bias against conservatives, and had resisted taking action until this week, when Twitter fact-checked his own false statements.
item.dc:creator: Maggie Haberman and Kate Conger
item.media:description: President Trump spoke before signing an executive order on Thursday in the Oval Office. He was joined by Attorney General William P. Barr.

item.title: C.D.C. Suggests Big Changes to Offices: Temperature Checks and Desk Shields
item.description: Temperature checks, desk shields and no public transit: The guidelines would remake office life. Some may decide it’s easier to keep employees at home.
item.dc:creator: Matt Richtel
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: Alex Welsh for The New York Times
item.media:description: Offices at the University of California, Irvine’s infection prevention division last month, which has installed sneeze guards separating cubicles and encourages mask-wearing and hand-sanitizing.

item.title: F.B.I. Once Investigated Trump Campaign Adviser’s Ties to Egypt
item.description: Investigators scrutinized ties between Walid Phares and the Egyptian government. He was never charged with a crime.
item.dc:creator: Adam Goldman and Michael S. Schmidt
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates
item.media:credit: Samuel Corum/Anadolu Agency, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Walid Phares was among several advisers to the 2016 Trump campaign who elicited concerns at the F.B.I. because of overseas contacts.

item.title: House Approves Revisions to Paycheck Protection Program
item.description: It remains unclear how the legislation will be reconciled with a similar proposal in the Senate.
item.dc:creator: Emily Cochrane
item.category: Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)
item.media:credit: Bryan Anselm for The New York Times
item.media:description: Customers shopping through the window at a shoe store in Newark this month on the first day that nonessential businesses were allowed to open this month.

item.title: Why President Trump's Order on Social Media Could Harm Him
item.description: Without certain liability protections, companies like Twitter would have to be more aggressive about policing messages that press the boundaries — like the president’s.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker and Daisuke Wakabayashi
item.media:description: President Trump and his allies argue that social media companies have shown bias against conservatives and need to be reined in.

item.title: Management of Bailout Money Poses Political Test for Trump
item.description: Democrats are mobilizing to turn an economic bailout into a liability for President Trump even as some Republicans seek to embrace it.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport and Nick Corasaniti
item.category: Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)
item.media:description: The Trump administration has faced criticism for its carrying out of a small-business lending program, an issue Democrats are seizing on in the 2020 campaign.

item.title: Defying Trump, Twitter Doubles Down on Labeling Tweets
item.description: Twitter continued fact-checking posts even as President Trump threatened to limit protections for social media companies.
item.dc:creator: Kate Conger and Mike Isaac
item.media:description: Twitter headquarters in San Francisco.

item.title: The National Anthem’s Path to Fame Began With Little Fanfare
item.description: The song that became “The Star-Spangled Banner” had a modest debut in a newspaper. That first dated printing will be auctioned online at Christie’s.
item.dc:creator: James Barron

item.title: North Koreans Accused of Laundering $2.5 Billion for Nuclear Program
item.description: The Justice Department unsealed an indictment accusing nearly three dozen people of using shell companies to launder billions through the global financial system.
item.dc:creator: Katie Benner
item.media:credit: Kim Won Jin/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Kim Jong-un, the North Korean leader, recently returned to public view after a weekslong absence.

item.title: Soldier Stopped Shooting by Driving Into Gunman, Kansas Police Say
item.description: Master Sgt. David Royer, who is assigned to Fort Leavenworth, drove his car into a man who was firing “randomly” at drivers on a bridge between Kansas and Missouri, the police said.
item.dc:creator: Christine Hauser and Michael Levenson
item.media:credit: John Richmeier/Leavenworth Times, via Associated Press
item.media:description: The authorities gathering on the Centennial Bridge after a shooting near Leavenworth, Kan.

item.title: House Pulls Surveillance Measure After Trump Tells Republicans to Vote No
item.description: A compromise to reinstate expired F.B.I. powers to investigate terrorism and espionage collapsed amid bipartisan opposition.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Fandos and Charlie Savage
item.category: Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods
item.media:description: Speaker Nancy Pelosi said the House would instead negotiate with the Senate to bridge their differences.

item.title: Coronavirus and Fall 2020: How U.C. Merced Is Preparing to Reopen
item.description: Thursday: He has experience dealing with big disruptions. He’ll need it. Also: California sues the Trump administration — again.
item.dc:creator: Jill Cowan
item.media:credit: Max Whittaker for The New York Times
item.media:description: Students on the U.C. Merced campus in May 2018.

item.title: Pompeo Hits Out at China
item.description: A threat over Hong Kong, and controversy in the education world: This is your morning tip sheet.
item.dc:creator: Giovanni Russonello

item.title: Can You Get the Virus From a Surface?
item.description: And what else you need to know today.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times

item.title: Biden vs. Trump on Coronavirus Testing
item.description: While the president has left testing responsibilities to the states, his Democratic rival would harness the power of the federal government to drive testing down to the workplace.
item.dc:creator: Sheryl Gay Stolberg
item.media:credit: Alyssa Schukar for The New York Times
item.media:description: A coronavirus testing site in Arlington, Va. With over 100,000 Americans dead from the virus, testing has emerged as a major campaign issue.

item.title: Returning, and Awakening, to the Beauty of Rural Alabama
item.description: Having traveled to Alabama to wait out the coronavirus pandemic, a photographer reassesses his relationship with his childhood and his hometown.
item.dc:creator: Scott Baker

item.title: Couple Bilked Medicaid for $13 Million to Pay for Lavish Lifestyle, U.S. Says
item.description: Latisha and Timothy Harron spent the money on a private jet, shopping sprees at Tiffany, wine and clothes that they flaunted on social media, prosecutors said.
item.dc:creator: Neil Vigdor

item.title: They Predicted ‘The Crisis of 2020’ … in 1991. So How Does This End?
item.description: Two scholars coined the term millennial and developed a fan base for their grim theories. Now, the surviving one sees a generational realignment happening in American politics that does not bode well for Republicans.
item.dc:creator: Jeremy W. Peters
item.media:description: Neil Howe, left, and Bill Strauss in Washington in 2001. Their book “Generations” introduced a theory that American history unfolds in boom-to-bust cycles of roughly 80 years.

item.title: Camping in the West? Like Everything These Days, It’s Complicated
item.description: “Every state is different. In some states, every municipality is different.”
item.dc:creator: Steve Knopper
item.media:credit: Benjamin Rasmussen for The New York Times
item.media:description: Let’s get camping: Earlier this month, Douglas Hollabaugh set up a tent in Golden Gate Canyon State Park, outside of Golden, Colo.

item.title: U.S. to Expel Chinese Graduate Students With Ties to China’s Military Schools
item.description: The move is the latest in the Trump administration’s efforts to impose limits on Chinese students. But university officials say the government is paranoid, and that the United States will lose out.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong and Julian E. Barnes
item.media:description: People’s Liberation Army soldiers marching on Wednesday at the entrance of the Forbidden City in Beijing.

item.title: Senators Seek Answers on Coronavirus Protections at Guantánamo Bay
item.description: In a letter, they asked the Pentagon how the military is safeguarding troops and prisoners from an outbreak of Covid-19 given the base’s limited health care facilities.
item.dc:creator: Carol Rosenberg
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: The medical clinic at Guantanamo Bay’s detention center. Health care on the base is limited for detainees and service members.

item.title: Get Republicans to Vote Against Trump? This Group Will Spend $10 Million to Try
item.description: A new organization, Republican Voters Against Trump, is testing the premise of whether there are really any persuadable voters left.
item.dc:creator: Annie Karni
item.media:credit: Republicans for the Rule of Law
item.media:description: The group Republican Voters Against Trump has created a cache of 100 testimonial videos from voters explaining their decision to break with the party.

item.title: 23 Poets Laureate Receive Fellowships for Projects Around the U.S.
item.description: The program, now in its second year, was expanded from 13 poets in 2019 thanks to a $4.5 million grant from the Mellon Foundation.
item.dc:creator: Concepción de León
item.media:description: Honey Bell-Bey is the poet laureate for Cuyahoga County in Ohio, one of 23 recipients of fellowships from the Academy of American Poets.

item.title: U.S. Jobless Claims Pass 40 Million: Live Business Updates
item.description: The latest on stock market and business news during the coronavirus outbreak.
item.media:description: Lining up for food outside a church in Jackson Heights, Queens, on Tuesday.

item.title: Where Coronavirus Help on Facebook Is ‘Inherently Political’
item.description: Three young organizers in the Detroit area started a group for people to offer face masks, emergency cash or help navigating unemployment. They see it as part of a larger vision.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Medina
item.media:credit: Emily Rose Bennett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Justin Onwenu, an organizer of a Facebook group offering people help amid the health crisis, said, “For my age group, if we don’t walk away from this moment understanding there are things we really need to change, we will have failed.”

item.title: Trump Prepares Social Media Executive Order to Limit Protections
item.description: The move is almost certain to face a court challenge and signals the latest salvo by President Trump to crack down on online platforms.
item.dc:creator: Maggie Haberman and Kate Conger
item.media:description: President Trump and his supporters have long accused social media companies like Twitter of silencing conservative voices.

item.title: G.E., Which Traces Its Roots to Thomas Edison, Sells Its Lighting Business
item.description: The transaction represented a symbolic closing to G.E.’s opening chapters in the second Industrial Revolution.
item.dc:creator: Michael Levenson
item.media:description: General Electric, long synonymous with the light bulb, sold its lighting business to Savant Systems Inc., a home automation company based in Massachusetts.

item.title: Coronavirus Spread Speeds Up, Even as Nations Reopen: Live Coverage
item.description: In just the last week, even as come countries move to reopen, 700,000 new infections have been reported as the virus takes firmer hold in Latin America and the Middle East.
item.media:credit: Dado Galdieri for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Brazilian man praying at the grave of his grandfather, who died from Covid-19.

item.title: Rep. Sam Johnson of Texas Dies at 89
item.description: Mr. Johnson was a military pilot who spent years as a prisoner of war in Vietnam before serving more than two decades representing a Dallas-area district in Congress.
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
